content:
The Nasrid dynasty had a significant influence on the architecture of the Alcazaba of Málaga, apart from the Nazrid Palace. 

One of the most notable examples is the construction of the defensive walls surrounding the fortress, which were extended and reinforced by the Nasrids in the 13th and 14th centuries. These walls feature elements such as towers, gates, and a cistern for storing water that are characteristic of Islamic-Andalusian architecture.

Another important feature built during the Nasrid period is the Puerta de los Cuartos de Granada, which is an imposing gate through which visitors enter the fortress. The gate has a horseshoe arch and features intricate stucco and tilework decoration that is characteristic of Islamic-Andalusian art and design.

Additionally, the Nasrid dynasty made significant modifications and enhancements to the existing structures within the fortress, such as the creation of the Palace of the Governor and the construction of the Torre del Homenaje, or keep, which served as a lookout tower.

Overall, the Nasrids' influence on the architecture of the Alcazaba of Málaga, apart from the Nazrid Palace, is evident in the combination of simplicity and functionality with decorative elements, harmonious proportions and use of local resources, which characterize Islamic-Andalusian architecture.
